SiteThe application site comprises a vacant, ground floor commercial unit located on the southern side of Chiltern Drive. It has residential flats above. The site is located within the designated Chiltern Drive Local Centre.The application site was granted planning permission in 1987 for a change of use from an Estate Agency to Mortgage Brokers under application ref: 33702, however officers are not certain that the planning permission was subsequently implemented. No other planning permissions for a change of use have been submitted for the application site. The current proposal involves the change of use from a retail shop (Use Class E) to a nail and beauty salon (Use Class Sui Generis).Consultation24 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. RBK Environmental Health Officer - No objection subject to conditions.RBK Highways Officer - No objection.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are: -The principle of development;- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.Principle of developmentPolicy DM17 states that the Council will protect, manage and enhance all employment land and premises in local centres so that they continue to provide locally accessible goods, services and employment.Policy DM18 states that the Council will consider applications for new employment development (of an appropriate scale) in designated employment locations favourably.Officer comment: As mentioned above, the proposal would replace an existing vacant retail shop, and while the history of the use of the site is unclear, officers note that the premise was granted permission for a mortgage brokers in 1987, previously falling under an estate agency. Since it has not been demonstrated that another use has operated continuously for a period of more than 10 years, officers consider it likely that the application site does fall under an E Use Class. Officers note that the proposal would provide a nail and beauty salon, which would fall under Class Sui Generis Use. While there appear to be a few similar uses within Chiltern Drive Local Centre, officers note that it would not lead to a predominance of Sui Generis Use Classes within Chiltern Drive, and given that there are a number of vacant premises within the immediate vicinity, officers consider that the proposed use would be an appropriate use within the designated local centre. Further, by bringing a vacant unit back into use it would enhance the vitality and viability of Chiltern Drive, providing employment floorspace and employment opportunities.Officers note that the proposal does not seek any changes to the shopfront.  Any changes in this regard may require a separate planning permission and advertisement consent. Design When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposals would not involve any external alterations to the shopfront, and as such there would be no adverse impact upon the character and appearance of the property, or the immediate surrounding area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed hours of use would be 0900 - 1900 Mon - Sat and 1100 - 1800 on Sundays and Bank Holidays, which is considered to be acceptable. Given that the proposed use would not likely generate additional noise than a retail shop, officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of increased noise and disturbance. Further, given that the floorspace of the building would remain the same, with no changes to the shopfront, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light, or loss of privacy. Highways and ParkingPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer comment: Parking is not restricted within Chiltern Drive and the site has a Public Transport Accessibility Level (PTAL) score of 2 (poor), however Berrylands station is located approximately 100m from the proposed use.Officers note that no car parking for staff or customers is proposed, however given the close proximity of use to Berrylands station and that there are a number of parking spaces viewed on Chiltern Drive, officers consider the car parking provision to be acceptable.The London Plan would require a commercial space of this nature to provide 1 long stay cycle parking space and 1 short stay cycle parking space, and while the applicant has not provided details of the proposed cycle storage, officers consider that this could be secured via an appropriate condition in the event of an approval to ensure policy compliance.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site is a terraced property on the north side of The Triangle a designated local centre. The area is mixed use typically with commercial uses at ground floor and residential above. There is a service road to the rear and residential properties beyond.The site is not in a conservation area and the buildings and curtilage are not listed. The area has a PTAL rating of 2.ConsultationA total of 5 objections to the proposed development have been received. The objections are summarised as follows:- Access or traffic problems- Car park issues- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- Noise- Privacy- Unacceptable or incompatible useOfficer comment: The objections are considered in the officers assessment.  AssessmentThe proposal would create additional commercial floorspace in the form of storage for the existing commercial unit at ground floor and an additional residentional unit at first floor. The building is currently in mixed use and the proposed uses are considered to be compatible with and would not change the use of the existing site. It is considered that the principle of the proposed development is acceptable. The proposed development includes a 1 bed 2 person self contained residential unit. The floorplan is clearly annotated showing an internal floorspace of 46.1 sqm. The proposed accommodation would not meet the minimum internal space standard for a 1b 2p unit of 50 sqm as set out in table 3.3 of Policy D6 of the London Plan 2021.The proposal provides a balcony at the rear shown on the deposited plans to be 4.6sqm in area. The proposed amenity space would not meet either minimum space requirements set out in the London Plan (5sqm) or the Council's Residential Design SPD (10sqm) and as such the proposal would not accord with policies D6 of the London Plan and Policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Startegy and Policy Guidance 13 of the Council's adopted LDF Residential Design SPD. The London Plan is clear that where there is a local requirement that is higher than that of the London Plan the local threshold should be applied. Whilst it is acknowledged that there are a number of projections in built form at the rear of the terrace in which the application site forms part of at ground and first floor it is considered that the full width coverage, excessive depth and flat roof design are not a subordinate addition and by virtue of its size, siting and design the proposed extension would create an incongruous addition to the host property that would not be subordinate and would be a dominant and overbearing feature at the rear of the property and be visually intrusive in the views of the site form the surrounding area and would as such detract from the character and appearance of the host property and surrounding area. The porposal would not accord with policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.It would be expected that a development proposal would be an opportunity for the betterment of the host property and its surroundings and it is considered that the opportunity is not being taken in this intance. The host property currently comprises of commercial use at ground floor and residential use on the upper floors with a number of habitable rooms directly facing onto the application site. It is considered that the proposed development by virtue of its size, siting and design in close proximity to the existing 1st floor rear habitable room windows of 10 the Triangle would create an unnecessary sense of enclosure and cause harm to the outlook of the existing neighbouring occupiers and as such the proposal would not accord with policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The proposed development would be in close proximity to the rear gardens of Arundel and Dickerage Road to the north seperated only by the rear service road. It is considered that the proposed siting and design and proximity of the proposed development to the neighbouring rear gardens of those in Dickerage Road and Arundel Road at the rear of the site would be overlooked by the private amenity space and rear habitable room window of the proposed development resulting in a loss of privacy and would cause detrimental harm to the existing living conditions of the neighbouring occupiers and as such the proposal would not accord with policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.Whilst it is acknowledged that there may arise some noise from the private amenity space proposed it is considered that this likley to be no more intrusive than that of any other private amenity space and any instance of unsociable behaviour would be controlled by the powers of the The Control of Pollution Act 1974 or its subsequent equivalent. Whilst officers can sympathise with neighbouring occupiers perceived concerns it is considered it would be unreasonable to suggest that the proposed amenity space would prejudice the future living condions of neighbouring occupiers by way of noise. In addition it is considred that the proposed development would not cause undue harm to the provision of daylight/sunlight to neighbouring occupiers. The application site is located in a PTAL rated area of 2 and the London Plan Policy 6.1 would require a maximum of 0.75 parking spaces for a 1 bed unit in outer London in a PTAL zone of 2. Whilst this does not equate to at least one space being required for the proposed development it is reasonable to expect that the creation of 1 unit could create the demand for on street parking. As such it is considered that the applicant has failed to demonstrate that the proposed development would not exacerbate existing on-street parking demand or lead to congestion and in turn prejudice highway safety and such the proposal would not accord with paragraph 111 of the NPPF 2021 and Policies DM9 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2021.Planning Balance/ConclusionIn conclusion, whilst the proposal provides additional housing in the form of 1 net residential unit it is considerd that despite their being an absence of a 5 year housing plan in the borough the benifit of providing one additional residential unit does not outweigh the disbenefits of the proposed scheme outlined above and as such the proposed development is considered not to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.
